claim: If, in 2020, the school whose mailing street address is 14429 South Downey Avenue had adopted a year-round academic calendar, its average daily attendance would have increased by at least 3%.
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim ('If... had adopted a year-round academic calendar... would have increased'). It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
This claim is a **counterfactual** — it describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If... the school... had adopted a year-round academic calendar, its average daily attendance would have increased by at least 3%."

The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical changes. There is no way to verify from the data what the effect of adopting a year-round calendar would have been.

Per the classification rules, counterfactual claims must always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim ('If... had adopted a year-round academic calendar... would have increased'). It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always NOT ENOUGH INFO."}
```
